image.altText: A person wheels their trolley past the end of a supermarket aisle. They are blurred from the motion and are not identifiable.

props.synopsis: While Tasmanians can shop at 17 Coles and 32 Woolworth supermarkets, there are no Aldi — with the German-owned supermarket giant unlikely to open stores on the island in the near future, it has been revealed.

title.children: Aldis are almost everywhere — but why are there none in Tasmania?

image.altText: A man holds a bunch of bridles.

props.synopsis: The harness racing trainer at the centre of a report which made findings of race fixing, team driving and animal welfare breaches loses an injunction to overturn his "warning off" from Tasmanian racetracks.

title.children: Ben Yole has 17 harness racing horses set to run on Sunday, but the Supreme Court has delivered him a blow

image.altText: Three people in high-visibility vests walk through a lumberyard

props.synopsis: Tasmania's premier and Liberal backbencher Bridget Archer say it was a mistake for Peter Dutton to draw comparisons between the reactions to the Port Arthur massacre and pro-Palestine protests, but others have backed the Liberal leader in.

title.children: Bridget Archer says Dutton's Port Arthur comments 'inappropriate and somewhat bizarre' as others back leader

image.altText: A crop of a square video, showing a blonde woman wearing a dark blue flak jacket.

props.synopsis: A UNICEF aid worker recounts the moment her aid convoy, which had informed both parties in the Israel-Gaza conflict of its movements, was hit by bullets in Gaza.

title.children: Australian aid worker's convoy hit by bullets while delivering aid in Gaza

image.altText: a nsw police officer stands near police tape outside blacktown police station at a crime scene

props.synopsis: The two teenage boys were stabbed near a school on Power Street in Doonside on Friday afternoon, before both made their way to Blacktown Police Station with critical wounds.

title.children: Teenager dead, another in hospital after stabbings near school in Sydney's west

image.altText: Composite image

props.synopsis: There are reports of people having to be helped from their cars as heavy rainfall causes chaos in Perth's northern suburbs.

title.children: Shopping centre ceiling caves and people helped from flooded cars as Perth freak storm wreaks havoc

image.altText: emergency services at night outside a rural property

props.synopsis: Police were called to the property at Kilkivan on Friday afternoon after reports of a fight between two men.

title.children: Police shoot 42-year-old man after fatal stabbing near Gympie, Queensland

image.altText: A person carrying a box walks past piled displays of vegetables

props.synopsis: Australians are eating less of all major food groups, with fresh produce leading the decline, says a new report.

title.children: Australians are consuming less fruit, vegetables and milk — here's what that looks like

image.altText: An unidentifiable child rests their hand on their leg. Only their leg and hand are in focus.

props.synopsis: There's been a mixed response amongst Australian medical professionals after the release of England's Cass Review into the treatment of children with gender dysphoria. Here's what some of them had to say about the findings.

title.children: A review into how children with gender dysphoria are treated in England has been released. Here's what it means for Australia

image.altText: Two AFL players engage in a high five with both hands, delighted after kicking a goal.

props.synopsis: The Western Bulldogs and Bombers are both striving for their third win of the season when they face off at Docklands Stadium. Follow live.

title.children: Bombers storm away with 29-point win over Bulldogs at Docklands

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: More goals for Essendon as they run away with the match

image.altText: Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow of the Dolphins is seen on the sidelines after suffering an injury during the round six NRL match between the Brisbane Broncos and Dolphins at Suncorp Stadium, on April 12, 2024, in Brisbane, Australia.

props.synopsis: Dolphins talisman Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow has injured his hamstring as the Broncos claimed the honours in the battle of Brisbane. Earlier, the Storm snuck home against the Bulldogs.

title.children: Dolphins superstar injured as Broncos claim battle of Brisbane

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Match report: Tabuai-Fidow injured as Broncos claim battle of Brisbane
75' Storm take the lead with Blore try!

image.altText: OJ Simpson

props.synopsis: The death of the former footballer — who was acquitted of the murders of his ex-wife and her friend — is described as "no great loss to the world".

title.children: 'Good riddance': OJ Simpson's death prompts harsh reactions from Caitlyn Jenner and father of murder victim

image.altText: A close up of a white SUV driving on a highway.

props.synopsis: Before the glove and the acquittal, came the car chase, in which OJ Simpson led Los Angeles police on one of the slowest and most memorable pursuits of the 1990s.

title.children: The famous low-speed Bronco car chase that came before OJ Simpson's arrest

image.altText: A signed photo of Carl Ditterich kicking a football.

props.synopsis: Former AFL champion Carl Ditterich appears before the Melbourne Magistrates' Court charged with historical child sex offences relating to one victim in 1985.

title.children: AFL great Carl Ditterich charged with historical child sex offences

image.altText: NT Police Commissioner Michael Murphy standing at a lectern and looking up.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister says 25 police officers will temporarily relocate to Alice Springs until the end of June to provide support after the youth curfew lifts on Tuesday.

title.children: NT Police to send 25 extra officers to Alice Springs when curfew lifts

image.altText: Police walk along a street at night.

props.synopsis: Crime is just one symptom of the intractable tragedies unfolding in Central Australia. But as the media obsesses over this "crisis", the deeper issues are ignored, and it's First Nations communities that suffer.

title.children: While headlines shout about youth crime in Alice Springs, the greater danger lies beneath the surface

image.altText: Close up of Wagyu steak

props.synopsis: A Wagyu steak with "a satisfying silky mouthfeel" and 60 per cent marbling has been crowned Grand Champion at Australia's annual Wagyu Branded Beef Competition.

title.children: With experts saying they've 'seen nothing like it before', is this the best steak in Australia?

image.altText: Andrew Forrest

props.synopsis: Criminal charges against Meta Platforms, formerly Facebook, are discontinued in the WA District Court, after mining magnate Andrew Forrest targeted alleged scam advertisements used to defraud Australian investors.

title.children: Charges against Meta discontinued in WA after move by Andrew Forrest targeting false crypto ads

image.altText: A woman holds a bag over her face as she walks away from a courthouse.

props.synopsis: It's alleged the 46-year-old woman improperly accessed the Queensland Police Service database and sold the information of a domestic violence victim.

title.children: Queensland police employee suspended after allegedly selling details of domestic violence victim

image.altText: A few ambulances lined up at the bottom of a ramp at a hosptial.

props.synopsis: A proposal to ban ambulance ramping at Tasmanian hospitals, put forward by the Tasmanian Liberals, is effectively scrapped by the Department of Health after the nursing and midwifery union raised concerns about safety and staffing.

title.children: Tasmanian Liberals' plan to 'ban' ambulance ramping scrapped by Health Department

image.altText: An old man wears a hat and a mask and holds a book up to hide his face

props.synopsis: With media cameras in position outside court, paedophile John Wayne Millwood pulled an item from his satchel bag. He held it in front of his face as he walked past. The item had his victim's name on it.

title.children: As cameras followed him, a paedophile held up an item with his victim's name on it

image.altText: Two Australian men's athletes finish a 100m race, with the winner (left) looking to his right.

props.synopsis: Australia's fastest man Rohan Browning makes his first appearance at this year's national athletics championships, but as he eased into competition a new generation of sprinting talent took centre stage.

title.children: As Browning warms up and Lewis sits out, a rising sprint star steals the show at nationals

image.altText: A woman wearing a suit and walking outdoors looks at the camera and raises her hand

props.synopsis: Videos of Spanish soccer player Jenni Hermoso sunbaking on a yacht in Ibiza made global headlines in the days after last year's World Cup final in Sydney. Now, court documents filed in Madrid have detailed new allegations about harassment and intimidation in the days that followed.

title.children: The world watched an unwanted kiss. Now court documents have revealed allegations about what happened next

image.altText: An Australia Post worker delivers mail into a letterbox riding an electric bicycle.

props.synopsis: An overhaul of Australia's postal service begins next week, as Australia Post shifts to only deliver ordinary letters every second business day, and with slower delivery time frames.

title.children: AusPost to halve the days it delivers letters from Monday

image.altText: A group of pedestrians walking along a footpath by the Yarra River on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The BOM's first winter forecast of 2024 shows most of Australia having both minimum and maximum temperatures of about 1-2 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: BOM forecasts this winter will be one of Australia's warmest on record

image.altText: A three-panel collage of Bruce Springsteen, Kiss' Gene Simmons, and Katy Perry

props.synopsis: Superstar artists are selling their rights at blockbuster prices. But who's buying? What's driving this trend? And who benefits?

title.children: From Kiss to Katy Perry, many artists are letting go of their rights. Here's why

image.altText: the back of a man's head with traffic lights in the background

props.synopsis: A growing number of Aboriginal people are being struck and killed on Northern Territory roads. Indigenous leaders are sounding the alarm.

title.children: The NT has the highest rate of pedestrian deaths. One in four drivers doesn't stop

image.altText: A graphic with a man in the foreground and wind farms in the background

props.synopsis: Australians will be paying more for energy in the future and they're not yet prepared for that reality, says Alinta CEO Jeff Dimery.

title.children: Prepare for higher power bills, energy boss warns, as clean energy transition challenges pile up

image.altText: Yolande dressed as Cleopatra with a group in dress up including super woman

props.synopsis: The ABC previously revealed Yolonde Entsch had been engaged to facilitate youth workshops and women's empowerment programs by the company.

title.children: Warren Entsch blames 'dirty tactics' following claims he personally complained to company over wife's employment

image.altText: A bronze statue of a coal miner sitting on a bench.

props.synopsis: More than four years after Brad Duxbury was crushed by two tonnes of falling coal, Carborough Downs Mine Management has pleaded guilty to failing in its workplace safety obligations, which also led to the injury of another worker in a separate incident.

title.children: Carborough Downs mine operator pleads guilty to workplace safety shortfalls leading to death and injury

image.altText: An edited screengrab of Bluey showing dogs watching tv, where the image on screen is a dog watching Bluey on TV

props.synopsis: Videos of pups watching Bluey — and apparently enjoying it — often circulate on social media, with some suggesting the show's colours are particularly canine-friendly. But is there any science behind the idea?

title.children: Why do dogs love watching Bluey? An expert in animal behaviour has some theories

image.altText: Composite of Kardashian

props.synopsis: OJ Simpson's 1995 trial for the murder of his former wife would become "the trial of the century". It would also launch the Kardashians into a messy family drama.

title.children: OJ Simpson was known as 'Uncle OJ' to the Kardashians. But his murder trial would divide the now-famous reality TV family

image.altText: Bluey wearing headphones, sits on his front door step with her back to the camera.

props.synopsis: After weeks of speculation, a Bluey executive has confirmed the creators would like to make a feature-length movie, with the new episode intended to gauge interest.

title.children: 'It's no secret' extended Bluey episode is a test run for a movie, executive producer says

image.altText: A photo of OJ Simpson at his trial in the 90s on an old-school TV screen

props.synopsis: How much do most people really know about OJ and his history? Whether you remember the car chase like it was yesterday or are only just discovering the details, there is plenty of content out there that can teach you all you want to know.

title.children: Understanding OJ Simpson: The best shows, films and podcasts on the man and his crimes

image.altText: Long silver train from person on top of silver bus in outback

props.synopsis: The History Trust of South Australia has launched a campaign to raise money to restore Priscilla, the bus at the centre of the iconic 1994 Australian film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, which was long thought lost before being found in a paddock in New South Wales in 2019.

title.children: Long-lost Priscilla, Queen of the Desert bus to be restored to her former glory
